thread.title: Toronto woman's dog killed by police in coyote mistake
thread.title_full: Toronto woman's dog killed by police in coyote mistake - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Toronto woman's dog killed by police in coyote mistake
text:
A Toronto woman is demanding answers after her pet dog was run over and shot by police.
Karen Southerland claims Ontario Provincial Police killed her dog Merrick after mistaking it for a wild coyote.
Police were responding to reports of a large coyote roaming the streets of Collingwood when they took action.
"Even if it is a coyote or a raccoon or anything like that you just don't run animals over like that. It's just not right," Southerland told CBC News .
The Toronto Sun Karen Southerland holds a picture of her dog Merrick. In a shocking video posted online, a police vehicle can be seen running over the animal, beore continuing down the street, turning around and running over it again.
In a second clip, a police cruiser is seen and a single gunshot can be heard as the animal is killed.
In a news release, police defended their actions and said that “for the safety of the community police had to put down this animal.”
gofundme.com Merrick, who was elderly, blind and deaf, was killed by Ontario Provincial Police. But Southerland called Merrick her "sidekick" and said police had taken unnecessary action.
She added: "She's just an old dog that was kind of lost and running around and was mistaken for a rabid, vicious coyote that a cop felt he had to run over three times and then shoot her."
Locals said they are concerned with how police deal with animals, especially in residential areas containing children.
CP24.com In the video, the OPP vehicle can be seen running over the dog before an officer emerges and shoots it. Sarah Leggett, who posted the video on Facebook, said the animal was posing no danger when it was killed.
"To say it was aggressive, dangerous or rabid, there's no way,” she told CP24.com .
"I stood at the end of my driveway as it was right there and it didn't do anything."
OPP Acting Sgt. Lynda Cranney said police are unable to confirm whether the animal was a dog, and are investigating the incident.
“The OPP is looking into the circumstances surrounding the video and remains committed to the humane destruction of wildlife when it is a threat to public safety,” she said.
lhanna@nydailynews.com
